div.l: She gropith alwey further͗e with hir hond
And found the bedde and thought not but good
Because that the cradil bi it stood
⁊And wist not wher͗e she was for it was derk
But feir and wel she crepith vnto þe clerk
And lith full stille and haue caught a slepe
Wᵗithin a while this Iohn this clerc up lepe
And on this wif he leith on̄ fulle sore
So mery a night had she not before
He pⁱrikid hard and depe as her wer͗e madde
This celi lif han̄ thees two clerkꝭis hadde
Til þat the thirde cokke began̄ to sing
Aleyn̄ wext wery in the dawnyng
For he had swonken̄ al the long night
And seid farwel malyn̄ my swete wiȝt
Þe day is comen̄ I may no lenger abyde
But euermore where so I go or ride
I am þyne ovne clerc so haue I wele
Now dere leman̄ coth she farwele
But or thou go one thing I wil þee tell
Whan̄ þat thou gost home bi the melle
Right at the entree of the dore behinde
Þou shat a cake of half a busshel finde
Þat was y made of thyne ovne mele
Which that I halp̄ my selue forto stele
And good leman̄ god thee saue and kepe
And wᵗith that word almost she gan̄ to wepe
¶Aleyn rose vp̄pe ⁊and thought or þᵗat it dawe
I wyl go crepe in by my felawe
And founde the cradil wᵗith his hand anon̄
Be god coth he al wrong I haue mysgon̄
Myne hede is toty of my swink to nyght
That makis me I go not a right
I wote wele bi the cradle I haue mysgo
Here lithe the mylner͗e and his wif also
And furth he goth in tuenty deuel way
Into the bedde there as the mylner͗e la
